Figurative Meaning: To act without direction or purpose; to drift aimlessly
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: Estar sin rumbo o sin un objetivo claro
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Reflects imagery of the Erges River; common in border towns
First Example Sentence: Despois de perdê l traballu, andava de rêu fríu por las calles de Valverde.
Second Example Sentence: Nun ye bo andâ de rêu fríu; has de buscâ un camiño.
Third Example Sentence: A vida, si nun la guías, leva-te de rêu fríu.

Idiom (Fala): Tê mais cuento que l gatu del cura
Figurative Meaning: To be overly clever, sly, or cunning
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: Ser más astuto de lo necesario o con malas intenciones
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Popular in Eljas; refers to cunning pets that trick owners
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Fala): [ˈtɛ ˈmajʃ ˈkwẽ.tu ke l ˈɡa.tu ðel ˈku.ɾa]
First Example Sentence: Nun confíes en êle, que tê mais cuento que l gatu del cura.
Second Example Sentence: Ês mininu ya mostra que tê mais cuento que l gatu del cura.
Third Example Sentence: Mi irmán, pa evitâ trabayu, tê mais cuento que l gatu del cura.

Figurative Meaning: To be overwhelmed or not able to keep up with work
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: No poder con todo; estar desbordado
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Common phrase borrowed from Spanish but fully Fala-ized
First Example Sentence: Estamus con tanto traballu que nun damos abasto.
Second Example Sentence: Entre la horta y la casa, nun dou abasto.
Third Example Sentence: La xente del bar nun daba abasto en las festas.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Reflexive verb phrase in past tense
Figurative Meaning: To be left speechless or amazed
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Common in children’s speech and stories
First Example Sentence: Cando viu l castillu, ficó-se coa boca abiertia.
Second Example Sentence: Ficamus tolos coa boca abiertia coa sorpresa.
Third Example Sentence: Ela ficó-se coa boca abiertia con l regalo.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Infinitive phrase with object pronoun and idiomatic noun
Figurative Meaning: To not take something seriously; to joke about everything
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: Tomarse todo a broma o sin seriedad
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Widespread in humor across Sierra de Gata
First Example Sentence: Nun podis tomâ-las a chunga nun tema asina serio.
Second Example Sentence: Sempre tomas las cousas a chunga, xa che vale.
Third Example Sentence: Tomâ-las a chunga pode creâ malentendius.

Idiom (Fala): Sê mais pesau que una moía de feira
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Refers to annoying vendors at rural fairs
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Fala): [ˈse ˈmajʃ peˈsaw ke ˈu.na ˈmo.ja ðɨ ˈfɐj.ɾa]
First Example Sentence: Ê rapaz sê mais pesau que una moía de feira.
Second Example Sentence: Tás sêndo mais pesau que una moía de feira, home.
Third Example Sentence: Nun sejas asina, que ya pareces moía de feira.

Figurative Meaning: To be deceitful or play both sides
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: Jugar sucio o con doble intención
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Card games symbolism from local taverns
First Example Sentence: Nun se pode fiâ d’êle, que xogâ con duas baralhas.
Second Example Sentence: Tás xogandu con duas baralhas, cuidado.
Third Example Sentence: Si xogas con duas baralhas, acabas por perdê.

Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: Tener mucha cara o ser muy descarado
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: ‘Cara de pau’—wooden face—is a metaphor from Lusophone culture
First Example Sentence: Ê tê la cara de pau de pedî emprestá sin vergüença.
Second Example Sentence: Tás con la cara de pau, ben que lo sabes.
Third Example Sentence: Que cara de pau tení, meu Deus!

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Imperative clause with negated scalar adverb
Figurative Meaning: Used to dismiss or criticize sarcastically; means quite the opposite of what’s said
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Used in Sierra de Gata to downplay or amplify emotions
First Example Sentence: Andâ que nun ye pouco, ya se cre l rei.
Second Example Sentence: Vino con humus caseiru... andâ que nun ye pouco.
Third Example Sentence: Pidi-o perdón... andâ que nun ye pouco!

Idiom (Fala): Traî l rabu entre las pernas
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Likens to defeated dogs, known metaphor in all Fala villages
First Example Sentence: Despois da discusión, traêu l rabu entre las pernas.
Second Example Sentence: Traî l rabu entre las pernas como si nada.
Third Example Sentence: Nun voltes traî l rabu entre las pernas, fala claro!
